title: Theorems on Similarity of Triangles by Proportion
text:

• Tranversal Proportionality Theorem
• Triangle Angle Bisector Theorem


At the end of this lesson, you are expected to: solve and apply theorems on similarity of triangles using:
• Triangle Proportionality Theorem;
• Transversal Proportionality Theorem; and
• Triangle Angle Bisector Theorem.



Instructions: Identify which of the following figures shows parallel lines or congruent angles. Write Yes if it is and No when it is not.








In this lesson, it is very important to identify the parallel lines and congruent angles in a triangle . In order to solve the problem, apply the following theorems on similar triangles by proportion. Below are some of the theorems that you need to know.


















Below are examples of the theorems on similarity of triangles by proportion.






























As you have observed, examples 3, 4, and 5 have the same given; however, the proportionality or formula used are different from each other. Therefore, even though transversal proportionality theorem have three possible proportionality or formula, you only have to choose one that suits the proportionality problem to be solved.































A. TRIANGLE PROPORTIONALITY THEOREM
If a line parallel to one side of a triangle intersects the other two sides of the triangle, then the line divides these two sides proportionally.
B. TRANSVERSAL PROPORTIONALITY THEOREM
If three or more parallel lines are cut by two transversals, then they divide the transversals proportionally.
C. TRIANGLE ANGLE BISECTOR THEOREM
An angle bisector of an angle of a triangle divides the opposite side in two segments that are proportional to the other two sides of the triangle.

title: Right Triangle Similarity Theorems
text:
Theorems


Theorems
Two triangles are similar if their corresponding angles are congruent. In effect, the corresponding sides of similar triangles are proportional. So far, you have learned three triangle similarity theorems: AA similarity postulate, SSS and SAS similarity theorems.
